arch:property.oc:show_val: This locus was designated as a surface because of the presence of smooth stones and flat-lying pottery sherds that extends from the southeast to the northwest corner of the trench, that was not revealed in L163. We took a HAP sample of the best preserved section of the surface, which has the dimesions of 50x50x5 cm. We chose this section also because it had contained the highest concentration of finds in the previous locus, L156. The surface was consistent from the middle of the locus to the southeastern corner of the trench, but was patchy from the middle of the locus to the northwest corner of the trench.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

arch:property.oc:show_val: soil and stone, with pottery and bone inclusions
L159, the wall L157, supra-surface L163, L162
Stones, both large and small, no consistent size, potterry and bone inclusions
